titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: At half past seven O’Clock this morning the Stage from Boston to Plymouth stop’d at my door in Quincy— Mr Isaac P. Davis and Mr Peter C. Brooks were in it—my Son Charles and I immediately joined them, and the Stage proceeded to Plymouth where we arrived at 1/2 past12 at Noon— We came through Hingham, Scituate, Hanover 4. Corners, Pembroke Duxbury and Kingston— There were three women in the Stage, one of them with a child under two years old, very quiet— She left the Stage at Scituate and one of the other women at Kingston— There were also three other men in the Stage who were and remained strangers to us— There is comparatively very little improvement of the Country from Hingham to Plymouth— The appearance of it is however pleasing—the Season has been fine and the verdure is yet upon the fields and upon the trees— Indian corn, and apple Orchards just ripening— Groves of pitchpine trees with sapling black Oaks mark the approach to Plymouth— We stop’d at Mrs Nicholson’s, where we met several Gentlemen boarders— Before and after dinner we had several visitors—Mr Thomas and Joseph Morton Davis, Mr Russell and his Son—Dr. Zaccheus Bartlett—A Son of judge Thomas at whose house I lodged in 1802 Dr Heyward Dr Thacher—Mr Russell a member of the House of Representatives and Isaac Lothrop Hedge one of the Senators of the County— We visited the registry of Deeds and saw the records of the first settlement in 1620— The town Hall and the enclosed fragment of the primitive rock— The remainder of the rock on the wharf—the New Meeting house of Dr Kendall—and grave yard on the brow of the Hill— We had visitors again in the Evening—some of whom left us to attend the wedding of Ralph Waldo Emerson with Miss Jackson

15. VI:5. Tuesday—rose with the Sun— Visits from Dr Kendall, Dr Winslow Warren, and several of our yesterday’s visitors again— We ordered our baggage to be sent on by the Stage to Sandwich, and after breakfast went in a barouche and pair to Manomet Pond—to a House kept by a man named Holmes— Thence Charles and I with Mr Morton Davis and Mr Charles Hedge went out in a small boat and caught a few fish I caught myself two Cod; but the tide was low and a heavy surf though with fine weather— We dined at Holmes’s—Dr. Thacher 82. Dr Heyward Mr Russell and his Son—Thomas and Morton Davis and Charles Hedges dined there with us— At 4. P.M. we took the Barouche and came 12 1/2 miles to Sandwich, chiefly through Pine woods and Sands— Athouse in Sandwich we meet Mr Walker the Minister of Charlestown and Mrs Walker— He said he was going upon a mission to the Marshpee tribe of Indians— Mr and Mrs Heyward the latter a beautiful daughter of Judge M’lean of the U.S. Supreme Court Mr Emmons and Mrs Gedney King and Mr King— All persons from Boston who come to pass a week or weeks here in pursuit of amusement or of health We spent the Evening with this party—by the side of a good fire which we have needed both last Evening and this— Since I left home yesterday morning I had found no opportunity to write till now, and I availed myself of a comfortable bed-chamber to write a short Letter to my wife, and also the preceding and this page. I sought for the Comet, but in vain.
16. VI. Wednesday— From Sandwich to Woodville Falmouth

My late hours last Night delayed my rising, till with the Sun We breakfasted at Seven, and Mr and Mrs King immediately after departed in the Stage for Boston— Mr Brooks, Mr Davis Charles and I went in our Barouche to the old village of Sandwich where I had been once in my life before—that is in April 1787. 48 years have since passed away, but we passed by the House where old General Freeman then resided, and the new Meeting House on the spot where the old one stood in which we saw our Tutor Jonathan Burr ordained— The Pond, the Brook and the Waterfall are still there with all their lively remembrances, but there is now, besides a very extensive glasshouse establishment, belonging to Mr Deming Jarves, which we now visited, and over every part of which we went— It is far less extensive than that of Dr Dyott, at Kensington near Philadelphia; but there are here 350. workmen and boys employed at wages from 9 to 25 dollars a week—and they not only make here the same sort of pressed glass which I had seen made there, but Mr Jarves claims to be the inventor of it and that it was first made here. We returned and dined at Hinckley’s tavern with the company we had left there, and with the addition of Mr Merrick the Minister of the Parish where Mr Burr had been settled— Mr Emmons had been out to hunt Deer, but lost his dog and returned without game— At half-past two we took again to the Barouche, and came across Cape Cod, through Falmouth, to Wood’s Hole, or Woodville. At North Falmouth, we had some conversation with the Postmaster Nye— At half past 6, we arrived at the tavern kept by J. Webster and sent for an old Sea Captain Hatch who came and agreed to go out with Mr Davis and me early tomorrow Morning to fish for the Tautaug or Black fish, and the Scuphaug or White fish— There is now no company at Woodville; but it is a Summer resort for valetudenarians from Boston, and Mr Brooks’s son Edward with William Sturgis and their families were some weeks here during the late Summer Season.
17. V. Thursday.— From Woodville to Nantucket—

I rose at 5. O’Clock, and Mr Davis and I went out with Captain Hatch in a fishing boat into Martha’s vineyard Sound, to fish for Tautaug and Scuphaug—otherwise called Black fish and white fish— We caught 8 or ten of the first and one of the latter which resembles a large silver fish. But our time was limited— I caught only one large Tautaug, and at a quarter past 9 we were obliged to return to Woodville. We breakfasted at Webster’s Tavern, and at 10 O’Clock the Steamer Telegraph Captain Nathaniel Barker touched at the wharf and took us in— We dined on board the Boat, and arrived at 20 minutes past 2 at the Island and Town of Nantucket— We had on board the boat ten or twelve fellow passengers among whom was a methodist Minister named Lindsey, who gave me Dr Wilbur Fiske’s inaugural address as President of the Wesleyan University at Middletown Connecticut—21. Septr. 1831—An Address of the same Dr. Fisk to the Middletown Colonization Society 4. July 1835—and a Zion’s Herald extra—upon Slavery and against the abolitionists— At Nantucket we took lodgings at Starbuck’s Hotel, where we found Professor Silliman and his Son, and Robert Treat Paine who is here engaged in Astronomical observations for the geodesical map of the State— Professor Silliman is delivering a course of Lectures on Geology— Numbers of the Citizens of the Island visited us in the afternoon, among whom Mr Bunker of the Committee of Arrangements upon the delivery of Professor Silliman’s Lectures, who invited us to attend one of them this Evening which we did—from 7 till near 9 O’Clock— It was at the Town Hall— There was a full auditory of at least 300 persons—men and women, all neatly dress’d— The Lecture was on the primary formations of the earth, and the remains of gigantic animals chiefly of the Saurian, Lizard or Crocodile kind—
18. VI. Friday— Dinner at Siaskonset.

We had numerous visitors this morning among whom Mr Barker Burnell, Walter Folger, Dr Morton Collector of the Port, Mr Barrett, Mr Tuck, Mr Mitchell—&c— After Breakfast we visited the wharf from which we had a view of the Harbour— Then Mr Philip Folger’s manufacture of Spermaceti Candles— Then the Athenaeum where is a small Library, and a collection of curiosities chiefly from the South-Sea Islands— Then the top of the Meeting house tower, whence we had a view of the whole Island, and distant prospects of Martha’s Vineyard the mainland of Cape-Cod, and of the boundless Ocean— Then a private School of thirty-five boys and girls kept by a Mr Pearce who told me he had attended my Lectures at Harvard University in 1808 and 1809— Then the School founded by Admiral Sir Isaac Coffin, for his relations of whom there are about 130 male and female in attendance— Then two Banks, of one of which Mr Burnell is Cashier— We then went to Siaskonsets head land on the South-side of the Island, where there is a small village, and where several of the Citizens of Sherburne have small neat country houses for Summer Residence— We visited an establishment of dunghill fowls, ducks and geese on the way belonging to two brothers Macy and kept by an Irishman.— We visited Saconet head dined at Mr Elkins’s on Chicken-chowder—Messrs. Burnell, Morton, Barrett, Mitchell, Tuck, R. T. Paine were of our dinner party— Bowls after dinner I went with Mr Philip Folger after dinner to his Country-House— Saw his wife, daughter and niece—returned to Town, visited Mr Walter Folger— Saw his Clock and Telescope, and closed the evening by attending Professor Silliman’s Lecture on tertiary formations.
19. VI. Saturday— From Nantucket to New-Bedford.

The hour of departure of the Steamer Telegraph was 9 of the morning; but she was out to tow a vessel into the harbour. The vessel ran aground and we waited for the boat a full hour upon the wharf. we visited a portrait painter named Swain—and the garden and green-house of Mr Aaron Mitchell raising peaches grapes and flowers from the deep sands— We took leave of Professor Silliman and his Son, Mr Burnell, Dr Morton, Philip Folger, Captain Myrick and sundry others, and at 10. A.M. loosened from the wharf. Mr Burnell promised to write to me about the Breakwater and the Bar— R. T. Paine embarked with us and landed at Holmes’s hole on Martha’s vineyard— We had as fellow passengers a company of Circus men with their whole establishment in three large baggage waggons and eight horses— They departed from the wharf with a chorus of horns clarinets and a drum— We touched only at Holmes’s Hole, and at Wood’s hole or Woodville, where we saw Captain Chase on the wharf— At half-past 3 we landed at New-Bedford with another flourish of horns and hautboys and Clarinets from our companions of the Circus— We were received by Mr Congdon, Chairman of the Selectmen of the Town, who had a Carriage in readiness to receive us. We preferred walking and were accompanied by all the Selectmen to our lodgings at Mrs Doubledays— Here we had numerous visitors, but soon walked out and round the town with Mr Arnold. We admired the finely splendid Palace-Houses of the Citizens, specially visited that of Mr Parker and viewed its magnificent furniture— We took tea spent the Evening and supped with Mr Arnold, who had a large party of Gentlemen to meet us— We saw also Mr Arnold’s garden— Returned to our lodgings at 11. P.M.

20. VI:15. Sunday— Heard MrEdes, from Leviticus 19.18—Thou shalt love thy neighbour as thyself— Visits from judge John Davis—Mr Morton Davis and Mr Rodman—and Mr Russell— Mr T. D. Eliot had accompanied us in the morning— After dinner we went with Mr Mack and heard Mr Joseph Angier, recently settled as the Minister of this Church, from Luke 10.27. “And he answering said, ‘Thou shalt love the Lord thy God with all thy heart, and with all thy soul, and with all thy strength, and with all thy mind[’]”— He omitted the remainder of the verse, which is the repetition of Mr Edes’s morning text from Leviticus— There is great difference of Style, as well as of delivery between these two young men.— Mr Edes’s manner being more plain and better adapted to the understanding of uncultivated minds—all his reasonings were pointed to the practical exercise of benevolence— Mr Angier ingeniously brought his discourse to the same conclusion, but he discussed somewhat largely the question what was to be understood by the word Love as applied to God, and very properly urged that it was a sentiment entirely different from that affection which is borne towards any earthly object. He observed that there was danger of mistaking one of these Sentiments for the other, and he noticed the cumulation of human faculties to which the commandment is applied— The Heart, the Soul, the strength and the mind— He did not however attempt to define those faculties to discriminate them from each other— The understanding, the affections, the reasoning faculty and the will, appear to be intended in the use of those words, and perhaps they were used only to enforce in the most emphatic manner, the precept— Mr. Russell one of our visitors reminded me that I had measured him in the year 1815 at London for a Passport— After the Church Service this afternoon, Mr Brooks and Mr I. P. Davis visited again at Mr Arnold’s, and saw his fine flower-garden and two green houses, and Mr Arnold himself closed the Evening with a visit to us— The boil on my hand almost disqualified me for writing, and I read in Bulwer’s England and Englishmen lent me by a fellow lodger at Mrs Doubleday’s, Mr Mack.
21. VI. Monday— From New-Bedford to Quincy.

My crippled hand makes me lose two morning hours before I rise— This morning we had several additional visitors, among whom Mr William Ratch 76 years of age, strong and hearty— He reminded me that he had travelled with me in the year 1825 in the Steamboat from Providence to New-York— C. H. Warren T. D. Eliot, Joseph Angier, Mr Tolman, and sundry others whose names it was impossible for me to recollect— At half past 8 we departed from New-Bedford in the Stage, and came through Fairhaven, Rochester, Middleborough, South-Bridgwater, West-Bridgwater Bridgwater and Randolph, to Dorchester, just beyond Milton Bridge There my Son Charles and I parted from our companions— Mr Brooks and Mr I. P. Davis, continued their journey to Boston. We engaged a Carriole and came home to Quincy where at half past five by God’s blessing we found all the family well.— We had among our fellow-travellers from New Bedford a very respectable Methodist preacher by the name of Mudge— The road from New-Bedford is fine all the way— The towns through which we passed all thrifty and prosperous At South Bridgwater we had an uncommonly good dinner, at an excellent inn—from Randolph to Milton Mills we came over the Blue-hill Turnpike, and found upon it a village two miles long of neat, comfortable and elegant dwelling Houses with two large Houses of worship, all a new Creation since the turnpike was opened, that is within the last fifteen years— We passed by East-Randolph, about two miles distant at the right hand as we came, exhibiting a village apparently as flourishing as that through which we passed— Near the whole Blue-hill turnpike and much of the New Bedford road is cut through with forests of Pitchpine, Black and white Oak, white maple, white Birch and Hornbeam, all but the Pitchpine small and young wood The largest trees are of the Button wood, Sycamore or Planetrees—as we approach Milton white Elms, Chesnuts—Hickories Ash, commence and the Locust trees cease— Indian Corn, Potatoes grazing and pasture lands are all the cultivation— There are in Middleborough four large ponds.
22 VI. Tuesday— Quincy

My Son Charles’s elder boy, who bears my name was this day two years old— Blessed be God for the gift of this child; and will it please the father of mercies that he may live to lead a virtuous an useful, and so far as happiness belongs to the condition of human existence a happy life— William Spear was here and I went with him down to the Mount Wollaston Beach, and viewed the piece of Land which Harry Hardwick has so often and so pertinaciously importuned me to sell to him— While we were there Alpheus Spear came down in his waggon and after him three other men with waggons to purchase Seaweed— They were from Randolph and Alpheus said the only one of them whom he knew was named Taper. I visited my Oaks, white walnuts, and pignut trees there which were in scanty bearing—none of the fruit ripe— I gathered nevertheless some nuts and acorns— Mrs T. B. Adams with her two daughters Mrs Angier and Elizabeth, and Louisa C. Smith dined and spent the day and Evening with us— Mr Beale and his daughter Anne, and E. Price Greenleaf were here in the Evening Charles went to Boston this morning, and returned to dine—with extreme difficulty I wrote a few minutes of the last two days, but am entirely disabled from writing as I intended some reflections upon the observations I had made in our weeks excursion—Plymouth, Sandwich, Falmouth Woodville—the Vineyard Sound, Nantucket and New Bedford offer a large field for great variety of comment, and remark; but the head partakes the imbecility of the hand—and my reflections pass away never to return— I found a Letter here from D. J. Pearce calling for an immediate answer which I cannot write— I visited my garden, Nursery, and Seminary but at this period the vegetation of the Season has almost entirely ceased— My Seminary has been weeded and a new soil surrounds my young seedling trees— The corner Seminary maple has not grown at all in my absence; but with perhaps twenty other plants from the Washington and Philadelphia seeds, promises to survive the approaching winter and become hereafter a lofty tree.
23. V.15. Wednesday

Charles went this morning to Boston, and returned to dine— He, and his wife, and Mary spent the Evening at Mrs T. B. Adams’s— I could not go, for the boil upon my right hand, which still inflames and swells without coming to a head— My wife sent for Dr Woodward, who came and lanced it, and ordered that a plaister of Basilicon ointment should be substituted to-morrow morning for the flax seed poultice which has succeeded that of bread and milk first applied after my return— With excessive difficulty, I journalised for yesterday but could write no more, and idled away the day—only hearing my grand children read— I avail myself also of this interruption of my intended occupations to read the Dissertations upon the Congress of Nations upon which I unwisely agreed to give an opinion. The American Peace Society have offered a prize of 1000 dollars for the best dissertation upon a Congress of Nations, as an Institution for the preservation of Peace. There are 13. competitors for this prize, and Chancellor Kent of New-York, Mr Daniel Webster and myself are appointed umpires to decide which of them is entitled to the prize— They were first s
24. V.15. Thursday

My hand is entirely disabled. I attempted to write the journal of yesterday but was obliged to desist and you see this is not my handwriting— Alpheus Spear came this morning about the renewal of his lease of the Mount Wollaston farm he was about an hour detailing to me all his resources to prove that he did not want it, but still as he was there he was quite willing to have it— He came to no precise proposition but said he wanted about 315 dollars expended in repairs on the lower barn, about nine hundred dollars to pull down the old house and build a new one, and from seventy five to one hundred dollars upon a watering place near the beach— He offered eight hundred dollars a year for rent; if I would pay all the taxes— I promised to go down next Tuesday if the weather should be fair to see how he proposes his repairs should be made and to talk over the affair with him again— Louisa C. Smith came to enquire how it went with my hand— I planted rows No. 8 and 9. cleared hazle bush patch row No. 8. twelve whole pears of the Corner tree on the patch in No. 9. twelve whole Orange pears—and in each a drill row of peach, plum, and cherry stones, apple seeds and acorns brought yesterday from Mount Wollaston—unable to write I have read a large part of Manuscript D on the Congress of Nations—one of the best that I have yet read but not worth a thousand dollars. he quotes unmercifully from Azuni—once in a while from Vattel, and once from Daniel Webster the last quotation very apt Mr Webster being one of the Judges to award the Prize— Charles’ Wife took a ride on horseback— I read some Letters from Horace Walpole to Sir Horace Mann—shivering with cold—
25. V. Friday

I Awoke between one and two oclock this morng with a pain of a sprained wrist and lay musing upon it from that time till after the clock struck five—then found myself utterly unable to write and began upon a large Manuscript Dissertation upon the Congress of Nations for the Abolition of War— Sent for Dr. Woodward who came and inspected my hand again and directed a liniment for the sprain, but that subsided before the liniment was procured and deprived it of the credit of effecting the cure— I wrote by the hand of my daughter Mary a Letter to Danl. Webster and packed up and dispatched for him four of the Dissertations upon the Congress of Nations—and then began to dig into the fifth— Charles went to Boston and returned to dine— E. Price Greenleaf came after dinner and inspected the seedling apple tree which he some weeks since budded for me— I answered a Letter from a Committee of the Boston Society for the diffusion of useful knowledge requesting me to deliver five or six Lectures or at least one Introductory Lecture upon suitable subjects to begin at about the last of next month
29. V. Tuesday.—

Morning at home; but inactive— Crippled hand— Charles went to Boston and returned to dine the Railway— Afternoon walk with Price Greenleaf to Mount Wollaston— Mrs Adams and Charles, fishing for Tom-Cod— Examined House and grounds— Overtaken by the rain— Mary and Charles’s wife rode on horseback— Copious rain all the Evening— Answers to judge Story and N. G. Smith
30. V. Wednesday

Morning walk with E. Price Greenleaf—round the Square from Arnold’s brook—stop’d at Brigham’s shop— W. Spear came and I went with him to the small Borland and Pine-hill wood lots. Sales to be advertised Day wasted— Congress of Nations Manuscripts— H. Walpole to H. Mann Charles went to Boston and returned to dine—
